nodes.bodyText:
I have a concern about the following scenario:
Query A fetched partition 'foo' but has not added to cache -> partition 'foo' was updated -> Query B called getPartitionNames and saw version change, thus invalidate the cache -> Query A put the old partition into cache -> Query B would read old partition
To be fair, this might be okay because it will be invalidated again when next similar query came in, and I don't think guava would fix this (google/guava#1881 has been opened for years). Is partition version an ever-increasing integer? If so, we might be able to guard against this. Otherwise this does not seem solvable because we cannot tell which version is the latest (which might still be okay).

I'm a bit hesitated about this approach because this method is not compatible with open source hive metastore, but adding as a default method might be okay.
One other option is to add cache functionality in our internal Hive metastore extension. The pro is that everything is hidden under the hood so we likely need zero changes in open source, but the con is that there would be a bit of logic duplication around caching, and we won't be able to pass version information around if needed.
Given partition cache is a loading cache, this map might be outdated. Could we store this information in partition cache and use getIfPresent? They might achieve similar goal.
nit: EXTRA_INFO
We don't have to make this a default method since the Hive implementation would be the default :)

nodes.bodyText: I think we should just call cacheConfig. getPartitionCacheTtl() regardless of isPartitionVersioningEnabled?

I feel this might be an overkill. Currently, we could only enable cache in an all-or-nothing fashion, and essentially we want to introduce a mode where we only enable cache for partitions. We are not really targeting a different caching strategy (ttl, refresh, size) for partitions.
Maybe we should introduce an Enum that is MetastoreCacheScope and have ALL and PARTITION in there, so that we could reuse the existing cache config.
Yeah having a Enum will be simpler.
nit: partitionExtraInfoFetcher -> partitionVersionFetcher
nit: partitionExtraInfoFetcher -> partitionVersionFetcher
nit: partitionExtraInfoFetcher -> partitionVersionFetcher
nit: partitionVersioningEnabled

It might be easier if we set all these caches in a switch statement based on cache scope. It might be easier to understand logically, but I acknowledge there would be a lot of redundancy.
Otherwise, we could use switch statement to set these values instead of a lot of ternary expressions.
Added a switch statement to set the cache configs.
What is gen?
I meant general. Renamed to cacheExpiresAfterWriteMillis
I see. We use gen for async php code and I guess my mind just drifts to the wrong side 😂
For ExtendedHiveMetastore, we might be able to make it non-default and actually implement them (throw unsupported) in the implementations?

nodes.bodyText: nit: how about moving the following assignments under case ALL, and throw for default?
This function is only called when partitionVersioningEnabled is true, so I'm wondering if we should actually treat version not existing as stale? I don't have preference, just a random thought.
I made changes to consider the partition stale if the version is empty. This will also help testing.
We probably could add some unit tests for this by calling getPartitionNamesByFilter in TestCachingHiveMetastore since this is the core logic for this feature.
Added testCachingWithPartitionVersioning() to TestCachingHiveMetastore

Not high priority for this PR, but might worth thinking about how to handle open partitions (where data is still actively being ingested to the partition, internally known as NRT). These partitions might not be cacheable across queries, especially partition stats.
